>From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>

>At 01:25 11/08/2004, you wrote:
> >So here's my dillemma.  My inputs are always in the range of +/- 1, 
>centered
> >around 0.  And it is always equally centered, such that it goes just as 
>much
> >above as below.
> >
> >NEAT, of course, captalizes on this fact.  By evolving networks that try
> >their hardest to always return '0' as the output, they minimize their 
>error.
> >. . without actually solving the problem they were asked to solve.
> >
> >What I need is a fitness function that penalizes for this.
>
>Can you not just make sure you include tests on plain-white and plain-black
>images in every generation?

>They presumably require outputs of +1 and -1 respectively?

No.  The inputs are scaled to represent the relative brightness of the input 
pixels, not their actual brightness.  Thus, the network will see a 
particular shape the same if it is nearly black as it will if it is gray, or 
if it is nearly white, or if it has high contrast or low contrast.

For example, compose an input image that consists of a linear gradient going 
from upper left to lower right.  Go from solid black to solid white.  The 
black will be given to the network as -1, and the white will be 1.

Make another that goes from black to gray.  Black will be given to the 
network as -1.  Gray will be 1.  Same shape, same inputs, even though the 
original image is different.

Same thing from gray to white.  Gray gets -1, white gets 1.  Every possible 
variant of a simple gradient from upper left to lower right going from 
darker to lighter will get the same exact inputs...unless the contrast 
within the sample is too small (less than 10% of total possible range).  In 
that case, the inputs are merely centered around 0, and the min and max will 
be something less than +/- 1.  The reason for that is to avoid amplifying 
minor noise in otherwise smooth areas of an image.

So, if I feed it all black, then the inputs will be all zeros.  If I feed it 
all white, the inputs will also be all zeros.  Not much value to that.

Yes, that does mean that the ouput has to be translated the reverse of how 
the inputs were translated.  But that's easy enough.  And the group at HP 
whose work I'm most interested in duplicating did in fact compare their 
results of translated inputs/outputs of various types with un-translated 
ones.  While they all worked, the translation method described gave them the 
best results, for what I would think are obvious reasons.  The network's job 
is easier!

>Or maybe the ability to do black and white should be the first part of your
>score function, even before averaging

Don't think so, not in this case.
